content.description: This route was bolted a couple of years ago but I haven't been able to work on it yet.  This project is NOT OPEN.

One of the original routes used to access and develop those to the right. Climbs the somewhat loose and scary face left of La Guarita. Easier "crack climbing" through the bottom of Guarita leads to critical horizontal placements and a wandering journey up and left through steep choss with a vital #0.5 placement. Pull the steepness, sling it all out long, and tiptoe right to the anchors for Guarita, or farther up and right to BAMR. Watch out for cacti!
content.location: Same as BAMR and La Gajuira. Do approach chimney to pedestal with anchor.

content.description:
This route is harder than it looks. It is pumpy and a bit on the spicy side. Long, sustained and fun. There is a ledge rest in the middle without which the red point would be at least a number grade harder.

 It has two distinct cruxes: one is lower down and mostly technical, the other very hight up involving powerful long moves.  Both cruxes are very tricky and will test your onsight skills.
content.location: Middle of the wall, starts out stepping out off a big rock and easy traverse moves unto a big ledge.

content.description: Mixed route. Named after a crag in Caracas. We chose to keep the style traditional because it makes for a very interesting climb. Not every day you get to place gear in limestone, unless you are in Caracas...
content.protection: half a traditional rack, sizes from 1/2" to 3"
content.location: Left of the chimney. Start on obvious crack and follow until you find bolts. Follow the bolts up to easier ground and place more gear, following the crack system until you find the anchors.

content.description:
This is an amazing climb. Incredible rock features and super technical movement all along. 

 Starts out just to the left of Men of Little Faith, go up on easy rock for a few feet and then get ready to rock and roll. The climbing is sustained for a while, pulling on crystalline rock incrustations and edges, then you get a rest and the game is on again. Be ready to fight with the skin of your teeth until the very end. What follows is thin, so bring your best dancing moves. It's not over until you clip the anchors.

Fun chimney climb that takes you to the top. All trad and very well protected. Perfect for someone learning to plug gear. The top of the chimney can be done in two ways: you can crawl through a hole, caving style, or you can climb on the outside. The second option make the climb considerably harder at about 5.9 for a short section. If you choose the hard way, make sure you place good gear before committing to the moves. This route is very long and a single 70mts rope WOULD NOT take you to the ground. There is an intermediate anchor for the sport route to the left that you can use. Also, if you choose to crawl the hole someone will need to climb the route to clean it, you can't do it while getting lowered. It is recommended to pitch-in (leader belays follower from the top) rather than the conventional sport crag lower-the-leader-and-top-rope style.
content.location: Obvious chimney that splits the wall. It actually forms a gap that separates the main wall (right) from the left side.

content.description:
Scramble up the chimney to a small ledge with anchors (~5.6). You can either belay from here or keep climbing, but you need to use this anchor to lower/clean this route. A 70mts rope DOES NOT suffice to get you to the ground from the top anchor. So please BE SAFE!

 From the ledge, step on the left side into the chimney and be ready to pull on small sharp holds and tricky feet, and hope your mittens are ready... Great technical climbing takes you to awesome steepness and pump funk... Meander up to lower angle rock. It does get easier at the end, but not before it get harder.

This route is phenomenal. Long, with multiple cruxes. It doesn't get more stars because it breaks out into three sections with no-hand rests in between.  The lower part is steep, with long moves on crimpers and underclings. The main crux is here right above a small roof. Then a little run out takes you to the first ledge rest, followed by a technical section reminiscent of traditional granite climbing (no worries no cams are necessary) and you get to the second ledge rest. Now you better have your big guns ready for a final long section of steep climbing over ledges and slopers. The pumpy headwall guards the anchors, very high off the deck, as a cherry on top of your sundae... you gotta earn that cherry. 

 A 70 meter rope is just barely enough to lower from the anchors. Please be careful.
content.location: At the very entrance of the Gap, starts on obvious pockets under a big flake.

content.description: This area is south side of a narrow gap behind the main pillar of the formation, most easily accessed from the south side, just all the way westward from The Sunny Side wall. This is essentially the back side of the Bowling Alley. This crag has amazing climbing in it, with really tall high quality routes and very interesting rock features. It's shaded in the morning and the afternoon, and sunny for a while in the middle of the day when the sun is up above the gap (timing changes by season). In the fall/winter it could get cold and windy in the shade. In late spring and summer you might want the shaded. In any case, the chasing sun and shade is as easy as moving a few paces one way or the other. Now, the base of this cliff is a real pain in the ass because it's steep and loose like a moraine affording it its very fitting name. Some work has been put into improving this situation, but more people need to be involved to make an appreciable difference. Still (did I say this already?) the climbing here is amazing.
